admreg: Europe and Central Asia,Europe and Central Asia
trustfund:
TF021274-PHRD 2-INST.DEV. OF STATE EXPORT-IMPORT,TF034068-LITHUANIA - PROPOSED EXPORT
            DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF034454-ECA REGION, MOLDOVA, LATVIA -
            PRIVATE SECTOR DEVELOPMENT,TF036961-UKRAINE - EXPORT DEVELOPMENT PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impacts, achieved through
            satisfactory performances by the Bank and Borrower. Two main
            lessons learned address: a) a positive feature of project
            design was that during the implementation of the project,
            the Bank combined a bottom up approach with top down
            pressures, aimed at improving the banking sector performance
            at the level of individual banks, as well as through a
            system of improved regulation and supervision, and better
            legal and accounting environment. The top down approach was
            pursued through extensive technical assistance and
            adjustment lending, particularly in the areas of the
            National Bank of Ukraine (NBU) regulation and supervision of
            banks, accounting reform, and the reform of the collateral
            law; b) major prerequisites for the successful project
            implementation were the requirement, and the program for
            institutional development of EXIM - State Export Import Bank
            of Ukraine - as a participating financial institution. Thus,
            project implementation not only provided EXIM with the funds
            for expanding its intermediary capacity, but more
            importantly, built-in incentives and provided necessary
            mechanisms for strengthening the Bank's financial and
            operational performance. The complementary technical
            assistance (TA), in addition to loan funds, allowed
            tailoring TA to the needs of EXIM, including being supported
            with capital investments, which brought prompt, more
            sustainable results, and increased synergy in using loan and
            TA resources. Further lessons address compliance with the
            covenants entailed in the Loan agreement, recommending that
            free limits for credit line disbursements be defined on the
            basis of total exposure towards any one customer, and, that
            the Bank allow sub-borrowing enterprises to use commercial
            practices, provided local legislation lays the foundation
            for basic procurement principles, with enterprises
            undergoing training in the area of procurement. It is worth
            noting that according to international best practices, one
            of the best ways to reduce credit risk is to broaden the
            appropriate credit product range. For example, permitting a
            finance lease scheme might have ensured EXIM the possibility
            to retain the ownership of the equipment. Leasing was not
            permitted under the existing loan agreement.
